questions.text: You are a doctor in armed forces and are tasked with doing medical examination of new recruits. Your next candidate has a blood report that mentions a FBS of 116 mg/dl. Which of the following terms will you use to describe this blood report?
questions.solution:
Answer is Option A) Impaired fasting glucose 

Impaired Fasting Glucose (IFG) term  is used when FBS is 100-125 mg/dl 

Impaired Glucose Tolerance (IGT) term is used when 2 hour value is between 140-199 mg/dl  

Criteria

Impaired Fasting Glucose (IFG)

Impaired Glucose Tolerance (IGT)

Pathophysiology:

IFG suggests early insulin resistance or beta-cell dysfunction.

IGT indicates a more pronounced glucose metabolism impairment.

 

 

Significance of Pre-diabetes

  • Increased Diabetes Risk: Higher likelihood of developing type 2 diabetes.
  • Cardiovascular Disease Risk: Linked to macrovascular issues (e.g., atherosclerosis), increasing risks of:
    • Myocardial infarction
    • Stroke
    • Peripheral vascular disease

questions.text: In type 1 DM, stage III of  beta cell destruction presents as which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C) ​​​​Autoimmune +, Symptomatic, Dysglycemia

Type 1 diabetes mellitus is autoimmune in etiology due to islet cell antibodies. stages of evolution of disease is as follows

Stage 1: Asymptomatic, Normoglycemia

Stage 2: Asymptomatic, Dysglycemia ( progressive beta cell dysfunction ) 

Stage 3: Symptomatic, Hyperglycemia

questions.text: Which of the following insulin preparations need to given once a week?
questions.solution:
Answer is A: Icodec 

Icodec is a once-weekly basal insulin with the longest duration (~7 days) among all insulins. It binds reversibily to albumin and is gradually released into the circulation. 
Glargine is a long-acting insulin (24 hrs) used once daily for basal coverage.
Degludec is an ultra-long acting insulin (>42 hrs) allowing flexible dosing.
Detemir lasts 16–20 hours and often requires twice-daily dosing.
Among these, icodec is the only insulin approved for once-weekly injection.

questions.text: Which of the following dermatological diseases is most specific to a patient of diabetes mellitus with RBS of 220 mg/dl and RIA showing low fasting insulin levels?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Necrobiosis lipidoica diabeticorum

The questions is asking about skin feature in type 1 DM which is Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum, presenting as yellow-brown, atrophic plaques with telangiectasia over the pretibial area. 

B: Note that overall diabetic dermopathy is the most common skin lesion in DM , as is seen as round, brown, atrophic macules on the shins due to microangiopathy.  

C: Acanthosis nigricans, a marker of insulin resistance, appears as velvety, hyperpigmented thickened plaques in neck, axillae, and groin especially in obese Type 2 DM.

D: Intertriginous candidiasis occurs due to immunosuppression and glycosuria, seen as erythematous patches with satellite pustules in skin folds like groin or inframammary area.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male with thalassemia major presents with fatigue, hyperpigmented skin, and recently diagnosed diabetes mellitus. He has been receiving regular blood transfusions since early childhood. On examination, he has discoloration of the skin shown below, mild hepatomegaly, and lab reports show elevated serum ferritin and fasting blood glucose of 180 mg/dL.Which of the following should not be done in the initial management of this patient?

choices.text: Monitor for cardiac iron overload with MRI T2

questions.solution:
Answer is C: Phlebotomy 

The patient has Bronze Diabetes, a form of diabetes associated with iron overload due to repeated blood transfusions in thalassemia major. This condition leads to impaired insulin secretion, resulting in hyperglycemia and characteristic skin changes.

In a thalassemia major patient with bronze diabetes, insulin therapy is essential to control hyperglycemia due to iron-induced β-cell damage. Iron chelation with agents like deferasirox is the appropriate method to reduce iron overload, as phlebotomy is contraindicated in such anemic patients. Monitoring for cardiac iron overload with MRI T2* is crucial due to the risk of siderotic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic factors is most strongly associated with an increased risk of developing Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is HLA-DR3 DR4 

HLA-DR3/DR4 haplotypes are strongly linked to increased susceptibility to T1DM. Mechanism: Loss of immune tolerance and progressive β-cell apoptosis in the pancreas by self CD4 cells. 

HLA DR2 is related to multiple sclerosis and goodpasture syndrome. HLA DR5 to perinicous anemia. HLA B27 is linked to anklyosing spondylitis.

questions.text: 25-year-old thin asymptomatic male is found to have fasting hyperglycemia during a routine checkup. His father and grandmother were diabetics.Genetic testing confirms a glucokinase mutation, consistent with MODY type 2. Which is correct managment?
questions.solution:
Correct answer : D: No treatment is required. 

Explanation:

  • MODY2 is characterized by mutations in the GCK gene, leading to stable mild hyperglycemia without requiring treatment.
  • Patients with this subtype typically maintain normal renal function and do not experience significant progression of diabetes.
  • In contrast in MC subtype MODY 3 that occurs due to HNF1A mutation, treatment is given with glipizide.

 

MODY (Maturity-Onset Diabetes of the Young)

  • A subtype of diabetes occurring in individuals under 25 years
  • Autosomal dominant inheritance
  • Family history often spans three or more generations
  • Caused by various genetic mutations with multiple subtypes

Subtypes and Genetic Mutations

MODY Subtypes

Subtype

Gene Mutated

Key Features

β-cell Glucose Sensing

MODY2

GCK

Mutations lead to altered glucose sensing

Results in mild, stable hyperglycemia

High fasting glucose; normal postprandial response

Rarely requires treatment; low risk of complications

β-cell Transcriptional Regulation

MODY1 

HNF4α
  • Involves mutations affecting β-cell function
  • Progressive diabetes requiring treatment

MODY3

HNF1α
  • Similar to MODY1 in progressive nature
  • Responds well to sulfonylureas

MODY5

HNF1β
  • Associated with renal abnormalities (e.g., cystic disease)
  • May cause genital malformations
  • Approximately 50% develop diabetes early in life

questions.text: Which of the following is most important intervention to reduce the progression of macrovascular complications of diabetes mellitus
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B) Tight BP control and statins

Strict BP control and control of dyslipidemia are main interventions to reduce macrovascular complications in diabetes, such as myocardial infarction and stroke. Statin therapy is essential to lower LDL cholesterol. Target BP is <130/80 mm Hg and Target LDL is < 70 mg/dl. 

 

Macrovascular Complications of Diabetes Mellitus:

Coronary circulation: Myocardial ischaemia/infarction.

  • Cerebral circulation: Transient ischaemic attack, stroke.
  • Peripheral circulation: Claudication, ischaemia.

Statistics:

Condition

Increased Rate in Diabetics

Cardiovascular death

1.7 times higher

Myocardial infarction

1.8 times greater

Stroke hospitalisation

1.5 times higher

Non-traumatic amputations

60% occur in diabetics

Extra mile: Risk of progression to blindness in DM is 25 times higher than normal population

questions.text: Which of the following is not a microvascular complication of diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C) Diabetic foot

 

Development of diabetic foot ulcer occurs due to peripheral arterial disease which is a macrovascular complication. 

 

Diabetic Microvascular Complications

  1. Diabetic retinopathy
  2. Diabetic nephropathy
  3. Diabetic neuropathy ( overall most common complication of DM) 

 

Key Microvascular Complications

Complication

Pathophysiology and Characteristics

Management Strategies

Diabetic Retinopathy

Microaneurysms

Neovascularization 

 

Initial screening:

Type I DM - 3 to 5 years after diagnosis

Type II DM - at the time of diagnosis

Diabetic Nephropathy

Early stages: hyperfiltration

Later stages: sustained proteinuria, nephrotic-range proteinuria, renal failure.

Microalbuminuria predicts progression in type 1, less reliable in type 2.

Aggressive blood pressure control (ACE inhibitors or ARBs),

Lifestyle changes (diet, exercise),

Possible renal replacement therapy in later stages

Diabetic Neuropathy

Earrliest involvement is symmetrical sensory polyneuropathy 

Pain management (anticonvulsants, antidepressants, topical agents) and lifestyle modifications (glycemic control, exercise) to manage symptoms and slow progression

Diabetic Foot Ulcers

Charcot neuroarthropathy: deformities in foot bones and joints.

Peripheral Vascular Disease: Impaired blood flow hampers wound healing and raises infection and gangrene risk. (macrovascular complication)

Debridement and Infection Control: Remove necrotic tissue and administer timely antibiotic therapy to manage infections.

Pressure Relief Strategies: Utilize custom insoles, orthotic footwear, total contact casts, or aircast boots to alleviate pressure on the ulcer.

Revascularization and Amputation: Consider angioplasty or surgery for neuro-ischemic ulcers; perform amputations if severe infection or gangrene is present.

questions.text: Which of the following is most important intervention for a newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus patient with HbA1c of 7%?

choices.text: Start cereals with low glycemic index

questions.solution:
Answer is A: Hypocaloric diet

Lifestyle modifications like hypocaloric diet( 500 Kcal restriction per day) is single most important intervention in newly diagnosed type 2DM. Carbohydrate counting is done for T1DM.

Consumption of cereals with low glycemic index is universal intervention in all diabetics to prevent post prandial spikes. 

Even a 5–10% weight loss through calorie restriction can dramatically improve insulin sensitivity, reduce HbA1c, and potentially lead to diabetes remission in early T2DM.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with abdominal pain, vomitting and prostration for past one day. O/E: pulse:100/min, BP: 100/60 mm Hg and RR=20/min with a fruity-smelling breath. Work up shows plasma glucose level of 350 mg/dL and a positive urine ketone test. Which of the following is next step for managment of this patient?

choices.text: Start regular insulin drip at 0.05–0.1 U/kg/hr

questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Perform ABG

 

This child is having presentation of diabetic ketoacidosis on clinical grounds . However the triad of DKA is not satisifed. Without complete diagnosis we dont start treatment. D is satisfied as RBS is > 200 mg/dl with symptoms, K is satisfied as urine ketones are present but there is no Acidosis report given in case presentation. We should first perform ABG to demonstrate low bicarbonate and low pH. It would take not more than few minutes and hence delay in treatment would not change the course of illness. Also note that vitals are decent and pateint does not need bolus IV fluids. 

 

If this patient was having crashing vitals then giving fluid bolus would have given been preference over all others. The sequence in managment of this patient will be 

1. Perform ABG ( check lactate levels for possibility of lactic acidosis or sepsis and check potassium levels) 

2. IV Fluid saline over 1 hour to correct dehydration + KCL added to IV fluid bottle 

3. Once K+ is ≥3.3 mEq/L and at least 1–2 hours of fluid therapy has been given, start regular insulin infusion at 0.05–0.1 U/kg/hr

4. If blood sugar falls to below 250 mg/dl change IV fluid to N/2 in 5%D 

5. Transition to subcutaneous insulin once patient is alert, eating, and metabolic parameters (AG, pH, bicarb) normalize

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents for a routine check-up. She is overweight but has no family history of diabetes or hypertension. According to the American Diabetes Association (ADA) guidelines, what is the most appropriate screening recommendation for her?

choices.text: No screening is necessary until age 60
Screen now and re-screen every 3 years if normal
Screen every year regardless of results
Screen only if symptoms of diabetes appear

questions.solution:
Correct answer is B) Screen now and re-screen every 3 years if normal

Explanation:

  • The American Diabetes Association recommends that adults aged 45 and older undergo screening for diabetes, regardless of risk factors.
  • Since the patient is 50 years old, she should be screened now, with rescreening every 3 years if the results are normal, ensuring early detection and intervention if necessary

questions.text: Which of the following is best for monitoring of diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Answer: A: Continous glucose monitoring 

Continous glucose monitoring measures real time glucose trends. It can detect nocturnal and silent hypoglycemia. It is unaffected by hemoglobinopathy and anemia. The biggest advantage is it gives immediate therapy adjustment opportunity. 

HbA1c can be affected by hemoglobinopathies, anemia and does not detect hypoglycemic episodes that occur in diabetics. Self monitoring of blood glucose is usually avoided by diabetics due to hassle of pricking self.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is the most appropriate for short-term monitoring of  glycemic control in a diabetic patient ?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Serum Fructosamine 

  • Fructosamine is the best choice for short-term glycemic control monitoring because it reflects average blood glucose levels over the past 2-3 weeks, allowing for timely adjustments in diabetes management.
  • This is crucial when monitoring changes after medication adjustments, unlike HbA1c, which indicates longer-term control over 2-3 months.

 

Fructosamine Testing:

Clinical Significance

  • Fructosamine: Formed by glucose binding to serum proteins (mainly albumin).
  • Duration of Reflection: Reflects average glucose levels over the last 2-3 weeks.

Advantages

  • Short-Term Monitoring: Ideal for assessing recent glycemic changes.
  • Unaffected by Hemoglobin Variants: Useful in cases like sickle cell disease or anaemia where HbA1c may be unreliable.
  • Fast & Convenient: No fasting is required; serum/plasma samples are used.

Reference Ranges

Population

Fructosamine Levels (µmol/L)

Non-diabetic

200–285

Diabetic (poor control)

Elevated above 285
  • Comparison to HbA1c: HbA1c reflects glucose over 2-3 months. (Option A ruled out)
  • Comparison to Fasting, Postprandial Plasma Glucose and OGTT: Provide only single-time-point results. (Options C & D ruled out)

questions.text: Glycosylated Hemoglobin is not reliable in diagnosis of which of the following types of diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Answer is A: Bronze diabetes 

  • Glycated Hemoglobin (HbA1c) effectively assesses overall glycemic control and is suitable for diagnosing diabetes in asymptomatic individuals.
  • Bronze diabetes is seen in thalassemia patients who are transfusion dependant. They develop hemochromatosis and iron excess damages the beta cells of pancreas leading to insulinopenia
  • Thalassemia patients have low HbA that will cause falsely low HbA1c

Causes of falsely low or normal HbA1c ( due to decreased RBC turnover ) 

 Causes of Falsely elevated HbA1c
  1. Hemolytic anemia
  2. Acute blood loss
  3. Chronic liver disease
  4. Post-splenectomy
  5. Reticulocytosis

1. B12/ folate deficiency

2. Iron deficiency anemia

questions.text: Which of the following values is not used for diagnosis of diabetes mellitus?

choices.text: Random Blood sugar of 250 mg/dl with classic symptoms
Fasting blood sugar of 140 mg/dl in asymptomatic patient
HbA1c value of 7.8% in asymptomatic patient

questions.solution:
Answer is B: Post prandial value of 200 mg/dl

Post prandial value is used for monitoring and follow up and not for diagnosis. In the ADA diagnosis table it is 2 hour value > 200 mg/dl that is used for diagnosis. 2 hour value is taken after glucose challenge of 75gm glucose and is not same as post prandial value. PP value can be influenced by type of meal taken. 

Random blood sugar> 200 mg/dl with classic symptoms is used for diagnosis of diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause drug-induced diabetes by impairing insulin secretion from the pancreas?
questions.solution:
Answer is B: Thiazide diuretics 

Thiazide diuretics are known to impair insulin secretion from the pancreas (possibly secondary to the hypokalemia induced by the thiazide diuretics), leading to increased blood glucose levels and a higher risk of developing diabetes.

 

Drugs That Can Cause Diabetes

Mechanism

Key Note

Increase insulin resistance (Option A ruled out)

Can cause temporary or type 2 diabetes

Thiazide diuretics

Impair insulin secretion from the pancreas (Option B)

Used to treat hypertension

Phenytoin

Possible liver-related mechanism (Option C ruled out)

Anticonvulsant medication

Drugs Affecting Glucose Levels but Not Directly Causing Diabetes

Drug

Effect

Interfere with urine glucose tests (Option D ruled out)

May cause false-positive glucose results

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to ER with a 2-day history of vomiting, abdominal pain and prostration. On examination, he is drowsy, with sunken eyes, dry tongue, cold extremities, a thready pulse of 140/min,  BP of 80/50 mmHg and RR =30/min. His RBS : 460 mg/dL, urine shows 4+ ketones and ABG shows pH= 7.2 , pC02 =20 mm Hg and HCO3 = 5 meq/L. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Start IV insulin infusion at 0.1 U/kg/hr
Start normal saline with insulin drip
Normal saline with insulin bolus followed insulin drip

questions.solution:
Answer is C: Give bolus of normal saline

The child presents with classical features of diabetic ketoacidosis and clinical signs of hypovolemic shock (thready pulse, hypotension, cold extremities, altered mental status).

  • In such a setting, the priority is rapid circulatory support to restore tissue perfusion.

  • A bolus of 10–20 mL/kg of normal saline should be administered over 30–60 minutes, and repeated if needed, until the pulse becomes palpable and perfusion improves.

  • Once perfusion is restored and the child is stabilized, gradual rehydration with normal saline over 48 hours can be started, adjusted for maintenance and deficit. 

  • Bolus of insulin has been discontinued as per latest ISPAD guidlines 

  • Insulin infusion is started only after 1–2 hours of fluid therapy and once serum potassium is known and ≥3.3 mEq/L.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Type 1.5 Diabetes Mellitus is incorrect?

choices.text: Characterized by autoimmune destruction of beta cells
Start basal bolus insulin if C- peptide > 0.8 ng/ml
It is often misdiagnosed as Type 2 DM

questions.solution:
Correct answer is option B) Start basal bolus insulin if C- peptide > 0.8 ng/ml

Type 1.5 DM or Latent Autoimmune Diabetes in Adults (LADA) is usually diagnosed in adults, often in their 20s to 30s, distinguishing it from Type 1 DM which commonly presents in childhood.

  1. If C-peptide > 0.8 ng/mL (Preserved Function): Start metformin or DPP-4 inhibitors or GLP-1 agonists. Avoid sulfonylureas as they deplete beta cells faster
  2. If C-peptide = 0.3–0.8 ng/mL (Moderate dysfunction): Use Basal insulin + metformin or DPP-4i
  3. If C-peptide < 0.3 ng/mL (Severe deficiency):Start basal-bolus or basal + mealtime insulin
